manipulated_prompt_obj.inputs:
human: Provide one single-word clue that relates to some of your team's words from the list below. You can choose to how many and to which words your clue relates to.
The goal is to have your partner guess all of your team's words based on the clues you give them, before the other team has uncovered all of theirs. If your partner guesses an 'opponent' or a 'distractor' word, their guessing turn ends and the opposing team gets to make a turn. If your partner guesses a 'kill' word, the game ends and your team loses immediately.
The more words your clue relates to, the quicker you can win the game, but the harder the associations may be to guess for your partner, so choose your clue word wisely. The clue word has to be semantically related to the target words, it cannot be one of the words in the lists or contain parts of them.

Always give your single-word clue and your comma-separated list of related target words in the following format and make your answers as short as possible, never include any other text than is required in this form:

CLUE: <WORD>
TARGETS: <TARGETS>

Your team words are: wind, hornet, baseball, fog, captain, meteorology, valley, flannel, cliff.
Your opponent's team words are: astronomy, clouds, bee, potato, apple, cave, tennis, soccer.
Distractor words are: mesa, rayon, bean, evergreen, typhoon, zoology, colonel.
The kill words are: radish. <sep> assistant:

raw_response_obj.response:
human: Provide one single-word clue that relates to some of your team's words from the list below. You can choose to how many and to which words your clue relates to.
The goal is to have your partner guess all of your team's words based on the clues you give them, before the other team has uncovered all of theirs. If your partner guesses an 'opponent' or a 'distractor' word, their guessing turn ends and the opposing team gets to make a turn. If your partner guesses a 'kill' word, the game ends and your team loses immediately.
The more words your clue relates to, the quicker you can win the game, but the harder the associations may be to guess for your partner, so choose your clue word wisely. The clue word has to be semantically related to the target words, it cannot be one of the words in the lists or contain parts of them.

Always give your single-word clue and your comma-separated list of related target words in the following format and make your answers as short as possible, never include any other text than is required in this form:

CLUE: <WORD>
TARGETS: <TARGETS>

Your team words are: wind, hornet, baseball, fog, captain, meteorology, valley, flannel, cliff.
Your opponent's team words are: astronomy, clouds, bee, potato, apple, cave, tennis, soccer.
Distractor words are: mesa, rayon, bean, evergreen, typhoon, zoology, colonel.
The kill words are: radish. <sep> assistant: <reasoning>
Let's tackle this clue-giving problem. The user's team has words like wind, hornet, baseball, fog, captain, meteorology, valley, flannel, cliff. I need to find a single-word clue that relates to as many of these as possible without being one of the words themselves or containing parts of them.

First, let's look for common themes. Wind and fog are weather-related. Meteorology is the study of weather, so that's connected. Hornet and bee are both insects, but the opponent's team has bee, so maybe not. Baseball is a sport, but how does that tie in? Captain could be a role in a team, maybe. Valley is a geographical feature. Flannel is a fabric, cliff is a rock formation. Hmm.

Wait, meteorology is the study of weather, so wind, fog, meteorology are all related. Maybe "weather" as a clue? But "weather" is a word in the opponent's team (clouds, astronomy, etc.), but the clue can't be one of the words in the lists. Wait, the clue can't be one of the words in the lists. Let me check: the user's team words are wind, hornet, baseball, fog, captain, meteorology, valley, flannel, cliff. Opponent's words are astronomy, clouds, bee, potato, apple, cave, tennis, soccer. Distractors: mesa, ray
